Fig 1 Fig. 2 HRTEM images of reduced solids. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Influence of the cobalt content on the catalytic performance (after 7 h of reaction) of the powder catalysts (DRM at 600 °C, W/F = 0.3 mg mL-1 min and CH4:CO2= 1:1). Fig 3 Fig. 4 Influence of temperature and feed composition on the catalytic performance (after 7 h of reaction) of the powder catalyst (13Co). (A) DRM at W/F = 0.3 mg mL-1 min and CH4:CO2= 1:1 and (B) DRM at W/F = 0.3 mg mL-1 min and CH4:CO2= 2:1. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Stability of the 13Co catalyst at 550 °C, under different reaction atmospheres and space velocities. (A) Reactant conversion and (B) H2/CO ratio. Fig 5 Fig. 6 In-situ DRIFT spectra over 13Co catalyst under exposure to CO2/inert and CH4/inert at 550 °C (A) and in DRM reaction with a CH4:CO2=1:1, operating at different temperatures (B). Fig 6 Fig. 7 Raman spectrum (A) and TGA/DTGA profile (B) of the used catalysts. Fig 7 Fig. 8 HRTEM image of the 13Co solid used in the stability test. Fig 8 Fig. 9 XRD pattern of the 13CoF‒o and 13CoF‒r foils. Fig 9 Fig. 10 Stability of the 13CoM-1 catalyst at 550 °C during 48 h (A) and optical images of the used monolith (B). Fig 10 Fig. 11 Catalytic performance of 13CoM‒2 structured catalyst at different W/F and CH4:CO2 relation. (A) Reactant conversion and (B) H2/CO ratio. Cobalt-based powder catalysts with different Co loadings were synthesized via wet impregnation using MgAl2O4 spinel as support. The catalytic properties of the solids were evaluated in the dry-reforming methane at different reaction temperatures and two CH4:CO2 ratios. The catalyst with higher cobalt content (13 %) presented superior performance due to increased Co0 species availability, confirmed by XPS analysis. Besides, this catalyst displayed remarkable resistance to carbon deposition at 550 °C and CH4:CO2 1: 1 ratio. In-situ DRIFT measurements demonstrated the formation and transformation of carbonate and hydrogen carbonate species during the DRM reaction, highlighting efficient CO2 and CH4 activation on the catalyst surface. Based on this data, a structured catalyst was deposited on top of the FeCrAlloy monolith, which was active, stable, selective for H2, and resistant against on/off cycles. Compared with the powder catalyst, the structured system displayed higher catalytic activity, possibly due to higher reducibility of metal species and improved heat transfer provided by the FeCrAlloy substrate. The results highlight the potential of Co-based structured catalysts for H2 or synthesis gas production processes. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Methane dry reforming Structured catalyst Hydrogen, Synthesis gas Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The dry reforming of methane (DRM) has attracted growing attention since it involves the reaction of methane with a greenhouse gas, CO2, to produce H2 and CO (CO2 + CH4 ↔ 2CO + 2H2, ΔH298K= 247 kJ/mol) [1]. The H2/CO ratio obtained from such a reaction (H2/CO = 1) is ideal for producing important chemical compounds (acetic acid, dimethyl ether, and oxy‒alcohols). The most active and selective catalysts for the DRM reaction usually contain noble metals (Ir, Pt, Ru, Pd, and Rh), which, due to their high cost and limited availability, are inaccessible on an industrial scale. As an alternative, formulations with transition metals such as Ni and Co have been studied, showing good performance in the reaction [2–10]. Ni-based catalysts are susceptible to deactivation due to undesirable phenomena such as sintering and coke deposition [2]. However, cobalt incorporation into Ni-based formulations has been demonstrated to improve the resistance to carbon deposition in the DRM reaction [11]. Several oxides, such as Al2O3, MgO, and SiO2 oxides, are the most commonly used supports [4,12]; nevertheless, some studies have reported the advantages of materials like MgAl2O4 as support of powder catalysts for the DRM reaction and combined reforming, operating at high temperatures (650–850 °C) [13,14]. Few studies have reported the performance of Co catalysts supported on MgAl2O4 for the DRM reaction [15]. Park et al. investigated a CoAl/MgAl2O4 powder system for the DRM reaction [15]. The authors evaluated the stability of the catalyst at 850 °C with a feed composition (CH4:CO2:inert) of 40:40:20. However, it is noteworthy that the stability test was performed at near equilibrium conditions. On the other hand, it has been shown that the addition of lanthanides (such as La, Sm, Nd, and Ce) as promoters in Co/Al2O3 catalysts provides a higher tolerance to carbon deposition, simultaneously increasing the catalytic activity [16,17]. Due to its high oxygen storage capacity, CeO2 is considered a good candidate for designing oxygen-supported catalysts with applications in reforming reactions [18]. However, solids based on cobalt and cerium oxides dispersed in MgAl2O4 spinel, which could provide stability and resistance to sintering, have not been investigated for the DRM reaction. It is well known that heat transfer efficiency is one of the main drawbacks in conventional flow reactors, where the catalyst is in a packed bed. In the case of endothermic reactions, such as the DRM, heat transfer in the catalytic bed is required for good performance. The implementation of metallic monoliths, with high thermal conductivity, mechanical resistance, and lower pressure drop, has been proposed to overcome the limitation of the packed bed reactors. In this sense, several authors have reported the good performance of Ni [19–21] and noble metal [22,23] based structured catalysts for SMR and DRM reactions. However, it is noteworthy that Co-based structured catalysts have been less studied in the literature for these reactions. The objective of the present work was to develop and evaluate the performance of Co/Ce/MgAl2O4 catalysts in the DRM reaction. First, powder catalysts with different Co content were evaluated at several reaction conditions (temperature, feed composition, contact time (W/F)). Therefore, a structured catalyst was developed using FeCrAlloy monoliths to intensify the process, whose composition was similar to that of the powder catalyst with improved catalytic performance. The structured catalyst was obtained by depositing a thin, homogeneous, and adherent layer of MgAl2O4 on the walls of the monolith, without the use of blinders or stabilizers, followed by the incorporation of metallic phases by immersing the monolith in aqueous solutions of the precursors. The structured system was evaluated at different reaction conditions and by simulating on/off cycles. In addition, the catalytic efficiency between the structured catalyst and the powder-based system was compared. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalytic systems based on Co‒Ce/MgAl2O4 Co and Ce‒based catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation using the MgAl2O4 spinel as support. The support was obtained from a viscous solution consisting of Mg(NO3)2·6H2O and a colloidal suspension of commercial alumina (AL20, Nyacol Nano Technologies, Inc.) as detailed in the methodology previously reported [24]. Aqueous solutions containing the metal precursors (Co(NO3)2·6H2O and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O) were prepared, with the required concentration to obtain the desired compositions (nominal loading of Co: 8 and 13 wt%, nominal loading of Ce: 8 wt%). The Co loading was selected based on the composition range previously reported for methane reforming reactions [25,26]. The support was placed in contact with the aqueous solutions and then taken to a rotary evaporator at 75 °C to remove excess water. The obtained solids were dried at 90 °C for 12 h and calcined at 650 °C for 3 h. The catalysts were denoted as xCo, where x is the Co wt% in the catalyst. 2.2 Structured systems FeCrAlloy monoliths of dimensions L = 4 cm, Ø= 2 cm, and 400 cpsi provided by Shanghai Wisdom Technologies were used. The monoliths were washed in an acetone/ultrasonic bath, dried, and calcined at 900 °C for 10 h. Then, they were immersed in the viscous solution obtained from the spinel precursors (colloidal alumina and Mg(NO3)2·6H2O). The rheological properties of the viscous mixture were previously studied [24]. Two immersions (1 min each) were performed, followed by blowing with compressed air and oven drying (with vacuum) at 90 °C/ 30 min. After the immersions were completed, the monoliths were dried at 90 °C for 2 h and calcined at 700 °C for 2 h. Then, the monoliths coated with MgAl2O4 were immersed in an aqueous solution of the metal precursors until the desired loading was obtained (nominal loading of Co: 13 wt%, nominal loading of Ce: 8 wt%). After that, the monoliths were dried in a vacuum at 90 °C for 12 h and calcined at 650 °C for 3 h, for the formation of the corresponding oxides (Co3O4 and CeO2); these were denoted as 13CoM‒1, 13CoM‒2 and 13CoM‒3, containing ∼14 and 9 wt% of Co and Ce, respectively. To facilitate the characterization of the coating by XRD and XPS, foils of 1 cm2 were obtained from the disassembly of a monolith calcined at 900 °C, which was treated in the same way as the FeCrAlloy monoliths. 13CoF‒o and 13CoF‒r corresponds to the nomenclature of the oxidized and reduced foils, respectively. 2.3 Characterization 2.3.1 X‒ray diffraction Diffraction patterns were collected using an Empyrean PANalytical, operated at 30 kV and 40 mA, using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm). The samples were analyzed with a scanning rate of 1° min−1 in the 2θ range from 20° to 80°. The crystalline phases were identified by matching with the JCPDS files. 2.3.2 Atomic absorption spectroscopy The quantification of cobalt content in the solid samples was conducted via atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) using a Shimadzu AA‒6300 atomic absorption spectrophotometer. The samples underwent dissolution employing an alkaline fusion method with KHSO4, followed by a subsequent dissolution step utilizing an HCl solution. 2.3.3 Raman spectroscopy The Raman spectra were recorded using a LabRam spectrometer (Horiba–Jobin–Yvon) coupled to an Olympus confocal microscope and equipped with a CCD detector cooled to about −70 °C using the Peltier effect. The excitation wavelength was 532 nm (diode‒pumped solid‒state laser). The laser power measured above the sample cell was 5 mW, with a collection time = 10 s and 10 accumulations. 2.3.4 X‒Ray photoelectron spectroscopy X‒Ray photoelectron spectra were collected using a multitechnique system (SPECS) with a dual Mg/Al X‒ray source and a PHOIBOS 150 hemispherical analyzer. The spectra were obtained with an Al Kα anode operated at 300 W. The pass energy was 30 eV with the fixed analyzer transmission mode (FAT). The pressure was kept at <10–9 Torr during the measurements. A flood gun was used to neutralize the charge. The samples were exsitu reduced to 600 °C in an H2(50 %)/N2 flow for 1 h. They were pressed, supported on the instrument sample holder, subjected to a reduction at H2(5 %)/Ar flow, for 10 min at 400 °C, and then evacuated to an ultra‒high vacuum for at least two hours before readings. The registered data were treated with the CasaXPS program (Casa Software Ltd., UK), considering the peak of C 1s at 284.6 eV as a reference. A Shirley‒type background was used to integrate and fit spectra of C 1s, O 1s, Al 2p, Mg 2p, and Ce 3d, except for Co 2p, where a linear background was used. 2.3.5 High‒resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) The reduced solids and one used in the reaction were analyzed by HRTEM using a JOEL model JEM‒2100 Plus microscope equipped with an Oxford model X‒MAX 65 T EDS. The images obtained were analyzed by the Digital Micrograph software. 2.3.6 Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) To determine the thickness and composition of the catalytic coating, the used monolith in the reaction was analyzed by SEM using a Phenom ProX Benchtop electron microscope equipped with an EDS analyzer. Before analysis, the monolith was dipped in a resin, followed by cutting and polishing. 2.3.7 Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) The thermogravimetric analysis of the used catalysts was recorded using a Mettler Toledo Star, TGA/SDTA 851 system. The solids (7 mg) were heated from 25 °C to 800 °C with a heating ramp of 10 °C min-1, under an air flow of 50 mLmin-1. The carbon formation was expressed as grams of carbon per gram of catalyst and the reaction time in hours (g C gcat -1h-1). 2.3.8 Temperature‒programmed oxidation (TPO) The TPO profile of the spent solid 13Co was determined from 25 to 700 °C (10 °C min-1) in an O2(5 %)/Ar mixture (60 mL min-1). The reactor outflow was fed to a methanation reactor operating at 400 °C with a H2 flow rate of 20 mL min-1; then, the outflow was analyzed by gas chromatography using a Shimadzu GC‒Chromatograph with FID detector. 2.3.9 In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFT) For the in-situ DRIFT analyses, a high-temperature and pressure cell (DiffusIRTM diffuse reflectance) with a ZnSe window attached to an IR Prestige-21 spectrometer was used. For the measurement, 20 mg of the sample was loaded into a porous ceramic cup. Spectra were taken with a spectral resolution of 4 cm-1. To study the interaction of the reduced solid with each of the reactant gases, the sample was initially heated in an N2 flux up to 600 °C, and then reduced for 1 h in an H2 (5 %)/Ar mixture. The sample was then cooled to 550 °C in an inert atmosphere. Subsequently, a CH4 (10 %)/N2 stream was fed to the cell for 10 min, with spectra recorded every minute. Then, a mixture containing CO2 (10 %)/N2 was fed for 15 min, with spectra taken every minute. To study the nature of the species formed during the DRM reaction at different temperatures, 20 mg of sample was pre-reduced as described above and then cooled to 450 °C in N2. Then, a reaction mixture containing 10 % CH4, 10 % CO2, and 80 % inert gas was added (total flow rate 50 mL min-1). Spectra were recorded between 450 °C and 600 °C after 1 and 5 min of reaction at each temperature. 2.3.10 Adherence test The adhesion assessment of the catalytic coating was carried out employing a Branson model 1210 ultrasonic bath. The monolith 13CoM‒3 was subjected to a 30 min immersion in acetone while exposed to ultrasonic waves at room temperature. The weight of the sample was measured before and after the test, and the result is expressed as the percentage of adhesion (%A). 2.4 Catalytic evaluation The powder catalysts were evaluated in the DRM reaction operating at atmospheric pressure at different temperatures (550 and 600 °C) and CH4:CO2 ratio. Two CH4:CO2 ratios were studied (1:1 and 2:1), corresponding to the feed compositions 32 %CH4/32 %CO2/36 %Ar and 60 %CH4/30 %CO2/10 %Ar, respectively. For conventional experiments, a packed bed of 50 mg of catalyst diluted with 50 mg of quartz (mesh 70) was loaded in a 9 mm diameter quartz reactor. The contact time, defined as the weight of the catalyst divided by the total feed flow rate (W/F), was 0.3 mg mL-1 min. A metal tubular reactor with a diameter slightly larger than that of the monoliths (40 mm) was used to evaluate the structured catalysts. The reaction temperature was controlled by a thermocouple located in the center of the monolith. The effect of contact time (W/F: 0.9, 1.9, and 3.9 mg mL-1 min) and feed composition on the structured catalyst performance was studied. Before the tests, all systems were subjected to a reduction treatment in a flow of 50 mL min-1 of H2(50 %)/Ar at 600 °C for 1 hr. The reaction products were analyzed by gas chromatography. The catalytic results were expressed in terms of CH4 and CO2 conversion and H2/CO ratio. The conversion (Xi%) of reactants and the H2/CO ratio were calculated from the following equations, where F(i)in and F(i)out refer to the molar flow rate at the inlet and at the outlet, respectively. (1) X C H 4 ( % ) = [ F ( C H 4 ) i n − F ( C H 4 ) o u t F ( C H 4 ) i n ] x 100 (2) X C O 2 ( % ) = [ F ( C O 2 ) i n − F ( C O 2 ) o u t F ( C O 2 ) i n ] x 100 (3) H 2 C O r a t i o = F ( H 2 ) o u t F ( C O ) o u t 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts based on Co‒Ce/MgAl2O4 The solids studied in this work, 8Co, and 13Co, showed a specific surface area of 78 and 76 m2 g-1, respectively (Table 1 ). The specific area decreased with the incorporation of the metallic phases on the MgAl2O4 support (145 m2 g-1), likely due to a partial blockage of pores or an effect of support dilution. As it can be observed in Table 1 below, the Co content, determined by atomic adsorption, was close to the nominal value for both catalysts. The X‒ray diffraction patterns of the fresh solids are presented in Fig. 1 . The reflections exhibited at 31.2°, 36.8°, 44.8°, 59.3° and 65.2° are attributed to the spinel support (JCPDS‒21‒1152) and also to cobalt oxide Co3O4 (JCPDS‒42‒1467), while those at 28.6°, 33.1°, 47.5° and 56.3° are assigned to the CeO2 phase (JCPDS‒34‒0394). The crystallite size (β) of the CeO2 phase was calculated using the Scherrer equation and considering the highest intensity reflection (2θ=28.6°), which was 9.0 and 9.7 for solids 8Co and 13Co, respectively. Due to the overlapping between the reflections of the MgAl2O4 and Co3O4 phases, it was not possible to determine the crystalline size of these phases. Therefore, to determine the presence of the Co phases, it was necessary to characterize the fresh solids by Raman. In this sense, bands attributed to the Co3O4 phase were evidenced by this technique (Fig. S1). Among the five Raman‒active modes characteristic of the cobalt oxide, only three were appreciated at 479, 526, and 689 cm-1, corresponding to Eg, F2g, and A1g modes, respectively, in agreement with results reported in the literature [27]. To analyze the species present after reduction, the catalysts were subjected to a reduction treatment as the one carried out prior to catalytic evaluation. The X‒ray diffraction patterns of the reduced samples, shown in Fig. 1, displayed the characteristic reflections of metallic cobalt (Co0) (JCPDS‒15‒0806), evident with the presence of reflections at 44.2° and 51.5°. However, it was not possible to determine its crystalline size since the main reflection of Co° coincided with one signal of the spinel phase. Additionally, the reflections at 36.5° and 42.4°, confirmed the presence of the CoO phase (JCPDS‒48‒1719). While no signals corresponding to cerium‒reduced phases were observed, a decrease in the crystallite size of the CeO2 phase could be evidenced after the reduction treatment (Table 1). The broadening of the CeO2 main reflection at 28.6° could be related to the presence of a reduced phase such as CeO1.66 whose main reflection would be located at 27.6° (JCPDS‒01‒089‒8434). High‒Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM) images of the reduced solids are shown in Fig. 2 , revealing the presence of nanometer‒sized particles with a tendency to agglomerate in both samples. The interplanar distances were determined by performing Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) on different particles and subsequently attributed to their corresponding crystalline phases. The interplanar distances observed were 4.66, 0.210, 0.254, 0.293, and 0.317 nm, which could be associated with the MgAl2O4 (111), Co0 (111), CoO (200), Ce2O3 (101) and CeO2 (111) phases, respectively. Nevertheless, it is essential to note that certain crystalline phases exhibit very close interplanar distances, leading to challenges in accurate assignment. For instance, the Co0 and Co2+ species display principal reflections with distances of 0.205 nm (111) and 0.213 nm (200), respectively, making it difficult to distinguish between these species. Similarly, this proximity in interplanar distances is observed for the Ce3+ (0.294 nm (101)) and Ce4+ (0.312 nm (111)) species. As a result, careful consideration and additional complementary techniques may be necessary for precise identification and characterization in such cases. The results obtained from both HRTEM and XRD analyses show agreement between the two techniques. The reduced solids were studied by XPS to determine the surface species and surface atomic ratios of the elements. XPS spectra of the Co 2p and Ce 3d core-level regions are presented in Fig. S2. Deconvolution of the spectra was performed to identify and quantify the species present on the surface of the catalysts. Table 2 provides information about the surface atomic ratios of the species present after reduction. The spectrum of the Co 2p zone (taken from 770 up to 815 eV, Fig. S2) exhibited the pairs of characteristic peaks of the spin‒orbital splitting (Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2). From the analysis, the contribution of two peaks assigned to Co0 and Con+ (with n = 2 and 3) could be observed, positioned at a binding energy of 777.6 and 780.7 eV for the 8Co catalyst, and of 777.6 and 780.5 eV for the 13Co catalyst. The shake‒up satellite signal associated with Co2+ species was located at 785.6 and 785.4 eV, respectively. According to the literature, the Isat/Imp ratio for Co2+ is 0.9; for the prepared catalysts, the found values were 0.9 (8Co) and 0.74 (for 13Co), suggesting the presence of Co2+ and Co2+/Co3+, respectively. The presence of Co3+ species in the 13Co solid could be associated with its higher cobalt content. The Co0/Con+ ratio (with n = 2 and 3) was higher in the 13Co (0.12), indicating higher reducibility of Co in this solid (Table 2). It is important to mention that, for the adjustment, the contribution of the cobalt L3M23M45 Auger transition located in the 760‒780 eV range, which overlaps with the Co 2p3/2 region when using the aluminum anode, was also considered. In this sense, two Auger signals were located at 780.9 and 778.2 eV for 8Co and 780.7 and 777.9 eV for 13Co. The parameters for the fit were taken from the literature [28]. The Ce 3d region exhibited peaks corresponding to the Ce3+ and Ce4+ species; for the latter, the main peak (used as a reference in the fit), was observed at a binding energy close to 916.0 eV. The Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio found was 0.20 and 0.27 for 8Co and 13Co, respectively, indicating more reduced Ce species in the 13Co solid. The presence of the Ce3+/Ce4+ redox couplet is important in the reforming reactions as it participates in removing carbonaceous species [5]. The surface Al/Mg ratio was close to the theoretical value (equal to 2). It has been reported that the Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio gives an indication of the oxygen vacancy content, suggesting that a higher Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio relates to a higher amount of oxygen vacancies [29]. In this sense, it is expected that the 13Co catalyst, with a higher Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio, would exhibit greater oxygen vacancies at the surface. For the powder catalysts, the O 1s spectrum (Fig. S2) exhibited three components that could be associated with lattice oxygen species (denoted as OL) at ∼530.2 eV, oxygen species near vacancies (denoted as OV) at ∼531.4 eV, and oxygen species related to hydroxyl groups or chemisorbed species (denoted as OC) at ∼532.2 eV [30,31]. Analyzing these data, it was possible to observe a higher amount of surface defects in the 13Co catalyst, consistent with the higher Ce3+/Ce4+ ratio observed for this system. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the solids The catalysts were evaluated in the DRM reaction at atmospheric pressure, varying the reaction temperature, the feed composition (CH4:CO2 ratio), and the W/F. Table 3 provides a summary of the analyzed reaction conditions. It is important to mention that all catalytic tests were performed under non-equilibrium conditions in order to observe differences in the systems. The equilibrium values were calculated with the STANJAN method, considering CH4, CO2, H2, CO, H2O, and Ar species in the reaction system. The contribution of the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS) was taken into account, while solid carbon was not considered. The CH4 and CO2 conversions and the H2/CO ratio at equilibrium conditions are summarized in Table 3. The catalytic performance of the solids with different cobalt content was compared at 600 °C, W/F = 0.3 mg mL-1.min, and CH4:CO2 ratio equal to 1:1. The catalytic results, after 7 h of reaction, showed that the system with higher Co content (13Co) has higher performance in terms of reactant conversion and H2 selectivity, compared to the one with lower metal content (8Co) (Fig. 3 ). Notably, the conversion of CO2 is higher than that of CH4, which could indicate that the reverse water gas shift reaction (RWSG) is taking place simultaneously as the DRM progresses [32]. Concerning the enhancement of reactant conversions at higher cobalt content, the increase in methane conversion was more significant than the increase observed in CO2 conversion. Some authors have mentioned that methane dissociation takes place on the active site, while CO2 conversion is initiated in the support [25,33]. Therefore, it is expected that an increase in metal content could lead to a rise in the number of active sites. The higher amount of surface Co0 species in the 13Co system, determined by XPS, could be responsible for better catalytic performance. Both catalysts were stable during the evaluation time; however, the 8Co solid showed a higher formation of carbonaceous deposits (0.0088 gC gcat -1 h-1, Table 3). The higher resistance to coke formation of the 13Co catalyst could be related to the higher amount of surface vacancies in the CeO2 phase of the 13Co solid, which participates in removing carbonaceous species. The effect of different wt% loadings of Co on the CO2 reforming of methane with steam was studied by Rahmat et al. employing Co‒MgAl2O4 based catalysts. These authors observed an increase in the conversions of CH4 and CO2 at Co loading between 5 and 25 wt%. The increasing percentage of CH4 conversion was attributed to the increased Co active sites. However, at a Co loading higher than 40 wt%, the conversions of CH4 and CO2 were observed to decline, which was attributed to a decrease in active sites due to particle agglomeration [25]. Considering that the catalyst with a higher Co content (13Co) exhibited higher performance, this solid was chosen to evaluate the effect of reaction temperature and feed composition under different reaction atmospheres and space velocities. 3.2.1 Influence of reaction temperature and feed composition Fig. 4 shows the CH4 and CO2 conversions and H2/CO ratios obtained by varying temperatures and the feed composition. As can be observed, an increase in the temperature resulted both in a higher reactant conversion and a slight increase in the H2/CO ratio due to the endothermic nature of the DRM reaction. At a CH4:CO2 ratio equal to 1:1, methane and CO2 conversions increased from 6.9 to 13.2 % to 13.4 and 18.4 %, when the temperature was increased from 550 to 600 °C, respectively (Fig. 4A). At higher temperature, an increase in the H2/CO (from 0.31 to 0.38) was also obtained. These behaviors were also exhibited in the tests carried out with the 2:1 ratio (Fig. 4B). In line with our results, Rad et al. explored the influence of temperature on feed conversion and H2/CO ratio using a Ni/Al2O3‒CeO2 catalyst [34]. The results of this research work revealed a progressive rise in reactant conversions and H2 selectivity as the temperature increased from 550 to 650 °C. On the other hand, an increase of CH4 composition in the feed resulted in a reduction of methane conversion while promoting an increase in CO2 conversion (Fig. 4B). These differences became more pronounced at 600 °C. Additionally, the H2/CO ratio exhibited an increase as the CH4 content in the feed was raised, with a more pronounced effect observed at 600 °C. Similar results have been reported in previous studies [34]. The differences observed in catalytic performance as a function of varying CH4 contents underscore the significance of feed composition in influencing the reaction kinetics and product selectivity in the dry reforming process [35]. Ayodele, et al. studied a ceria-supported cobalt (20 wt%) catalyst for DRM, obtaining a higher conversion at 750 °C [36]. However, the author did not report stability test of the catalyts. It is pertinent to highlight that the 13Co catalyst exhibited stability throughout the entire evaluation period under the reaction conditions. After the reaction, the spent catalysts were subjected to comprehensive characterization. It was observed that carbonaceous species were predominantly formed with an increase in methane content in the feed composition or at higher reaction temperature (Table 3). Notably, the carbon deposition on the 13Co catalyst evaluated at 550 °C with a CH4:CO2 ratio of 1:1was insignificant (0.0005 gC gcat -1 h-1). This finding will be further corroborated by the comprehensive characterization data discussed later, which confirms the remarkable resistance of this catalyst to coke formation under the conditions mentioned above. 3.2.2 Stability of the 13Co catalyst The catalyst with higher Co content was subjected to a stability test at different reaction atmospheres and reagent ratios. The performance of the 13Co catalyst was initially studied at 550 °C, W/F = 3.9 mg mL-1 min, and CH4:CO2 = 1:1 for 120 min (Fig. 5 ). Subsequently, the W/F was decreased to 0.9 mg mL-1 min, while increasing methane in the feed composition. After these tests, the catalyst remained at 550 °C in argon atmosphere for 900 min and subsequently reevaluated under the initial conditions to investigate its stability. It could be noted that the catalyst was stable under the reaction conditions explored since after 900 min in an inert atmosphere, the catalyst showed the same initial behavior. These findings suggest that the 13Co catalyst exhibits promising stability, positioning it as a potential candidate for developing structured catalysts. The use of structured catalysts, particularly those based on metallic monoliths, offers significant process intensification benefits, including improved mass and heat transfer, increased durability, and easier scalability. 3.2.3 Study of the interaction of reactants with the 13Co-catalyst by in-situ DRIFT To investigate the interaction of CO2 and CH4 with the catalyst surface and analyze the possible reaction intermediates, in-situ DRIFT measurements were carried out by feeding the reactant gases separately. For this, a mixture of CO2 (10 %)/inert gas was fed for 10 min at 600 °C over the previously reduced catalyst (600 °C for 1 h using a 5 % H2/N2 mixture), followed by exposure to a CH4 (10 %)/N2 mixture for 15 min. Fig. 6 A summarizes the spectra collected every minute. Under exposure to CO2, the formation of carbonate species in the 1300–1650 cm-1 range was observed. According to the literature, how CO2 adsorbs onto the catalyst, either by maintaining its linear geometry or by forming carbonate species, can distinguish between acidic and basic sites, respectively [37]. In this context, the bands centered at 1380 and 1550 cm-1 can be associated with carbonate species adsorbed on the basic sites of the catalyst. Based on the frequencies of these bands, they can be assigned to monodentate and bidentate carbonates, respectively [38]. Additionally, a band at 3700 cm-1, corresponding to hydroxyl groups on the support, was observed, with a noted decrease in intensity upon exposure to CO2. Upon switching to CH4/inert gas, a decrease in the band near 2300 cm-1, corresponding to gaseous CO2, was observed, along with a progressive modification of the bands associated with carbonate species. Two bands, at 1523 and 1650 cm-1 were observed under these conditions, which could be attributed to hydrogen carbonate (formate) species, probably arising from bidentate carbonates formed by CO2 adsorption. It has been reported that bidentate carbonate species can react with H* species from CH4 decomposition to generate formate species (OCOO* + H* → HCOO*), which subsequently form CO and H2 [5,11]. The band at 3600 cm⁻¹ is also characteristic of hydrogen carbonate [38]. The incipient bands near 1300 cm-1 are related to CHx species [5]. Furthermore, the band appearing at 3000 cm-1 corresponds to gaseous CH4. To better understand the DRM reaction mechanism, an in-situ DRIFT study was performed by feeding a 50 mL min-1 flow composed of CH4 (10 %)/CO2 (10 %)/N2 (80 %), while varying the temperature between 450 and 600 °C. The spectra collected after 5 min at each temperature are presented in Fig. 6B. It was observed that the bands at 3000 and 2300 cm-1, associated with the gaseous reactants (CH4 and CO2, respectively) interacting with the solid, decreased in intensity as the reaction temperature increased, indicating higher conversion of the reactants at higher temperatures. Although the reactants are consumed, no bands associated with CO adsorption on metallic sites typically observed between 1730 and 2100 cm-1 were detected. This could be related to the dispersion of the metallic sites, as CO desorption tends to be faster on larger metallic crystallites [39]. The pronounced bands between 1200 and 1600 cm-1 correspond to formates (hydrogen carbonates) [37]. It is noteworthy that the intensity of these bands did not vary with increasing temperature. The band at 3600 cm-1, characteristic of hydrogen carbonates, was also observed. These results suggest that the activation of the reactants, leading to the formation of CHx species (derived from CH4 activation) and CO3 2- (due to CO2 activation), facilitates the formation of hydrogen carbonate species, which subsequently transform and desorb as CO and H2. 3.3 Characterization of spent catalysts The solids used were characterized by different techniques to determine the nature of the post‒reaction chemical species and the presence/absence of carbonaceous deposits. The X‒ray diffraction patterns of the spent solids are shown in Fig. S3, confirming the preservation of the crystalline phases previously identified in the reduced samples. Compared to the reduced samples, an increase in the crystallite size of CeO2 in the spent catalysts was observed (Fig. S3). In the case of the samples tested at 600 °C, the presence of carbonaceous deposits became evident, given the reflection at 26°, which is characteristic of graphitic carbon (JCPDS‒01‒0640), while at 550 °C, the signal of graphitic carbon was not appreciated (Fig. S3). The Raman spectra of the solids used are shown in Fig. 7 A. With the exception of the solid tested at 550 °C and 1:1 ratio, all the other samples exhibited two pronounced peaks at 1350 and 1680 cm-1, which are attributed to the D and G bands of the sp2‒bonded carbon in graphitic structures. The G band is related to the crystallinity of the carbonaceous structures, while the D band is associated with density defects, making the ID/IG ratio an approximate measure of the nature of the deposited carbonaceous species. Remarkably, the ID/IG ratio found was equal to 1 for all catalysts, suggesting that the deposited carbonaceous species are similar in nature. Unlike the 600 °C tests, the samples tested at 550 °C revealed low carbonaceous deposits. In addition, a signal at 690 cm-1 corresponding to oxidized cobalt species could be seen only in the material tested at 550 °C with a CH4:CO2 ratio equal to 2:1. The absence of the bands corresponding to cobalt oxide may be due to the reduction treatment that leads to the formation of reduced cobalt species that have no active bands in Raman. On the other hand, it is believed that carbonaceous deposits could be covering the oxidized cobalt species. The amount of deposited carbon was determined by thermogravimetric analysis, and the resulting mass loss curves as a function of temperature are presented in Fig. 7B. In agreement with the observations from Raman and XRD analyses, the tests carried out at 600 °C showed higher coke deposition than those carried out at 550 °C. The maximum combustion temperature for the carbonaceous species was around 512 °C. Similar combustion temperatures have been reported in the literature for cobalt‒based catalysts [15]. The amount of carbon deposited in the 13Co solid used in the stability test was determined using Temperature‒Programmed Oxidation (TPO). The oxidation profile (Fig. S4) revealed an intense and narrow peak centered at 525 °C, which can be attributed to filamentous carbonaceous species [40]. A low‒intensity peak was also observed at 350 °C, which can be attributed to the combustion of amorphous carbonaceous species around the metal particles. Combustion temperatures higher than 600 °C have been reported in the literature for Ni‒Ce(La)/MgAl2O4 based catalysts [41]. HRTEM images showed abundant carbonaceous filaments with metal particles at the tip (Fig. 8 A‒B). Some carbonaceous species of the whisker type were also observed (Fig. 8A). Such carbonaceous structures are commonly observed in Ni and Co catalysts [12,15,16,42]. By estimating the interplanar distance from the FFT it was determined that the particles localized at the tips of the carbonaceous filaments could correspond to the Co0 (100 plane) and CoO (200 and 220 planes) phases (Fig. 8C‒E). 3.4 Development and characterization of the structured catalyst Given the performance of the 13Co powder catalyst, a structured catalyst with a similar composition was prepared; to verify the reproducibility of the preparation method, three monoliths were prepared. The structured systems obtained in this work (13MCo‒1, 13MCo‒2 and 13MCo‒3) loaded about 117 mg of catalytic material. The 13MCo‒1 and 13MCo‒2 monoliths were used in the DRM reaction, and the 13MCo‒3 monolith was used for the adhesion test. The percentage of adhesion obtained for the 13CoM‒3 catalyst (98 %) reflected that the preparation method allows to obtain highly adherent catalytic coatings. The characterization of the catalytic coating was performed on the prepared foils denoted as 13CoF‒o (fresh foil) and 13CoF‒r (reduced foil). The 13CoF‒o foil was analyzed by XRD, and the pattern displayed reflections corresponding to the catalytic layer and also those attributed to the FeCrAlloy substrate (44.4° and 64.5°) (Fig. 9 ). The reflection at 44.4° assigned mainly to metal substrate also coincides with the reflections of the spinel substrate and oxidized cobalt (Co3O4). It is important to mention that, compared to the powder catalysts, the reflections of the oxides and spinel on the 13CoF‒o foil are less intense, which could be due to the low thickness of the catalytic coating. In the reduced foil (13CoF‒r), a decrease in the reflections assigned to the CeO2 phase was noticed, probably due to the formation of reduced cerium phases. These phases could have a crystalline size below the detection limit of XRD, and were not observed in the X‒ray diffraction pattern. A broadening and downward shift of the reflection angle at 44.4°was also seen, which is possibly due to the contribution of the main metallic Co reflection, located at 44.2°. The reduced foil (13CoF‒r) was also analyzed by XPS (Fig. S2). The spectrum of the Co 2p zone, taken in the 760‒810 eV range, showed the pairs of peaks characteristic of spin‒orbital splitting (Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2). From the analysis, it was possible to observe the contribution of three peaks assigned to Co0 and Con+, positioned at a binding energy of 778.5 and 781.8 eV, respectively. The Co2+ satellite signal was located at 787.3 eV. The Co0 /Con+ ratio (with n = 2 and 3) was 0.23. The Ce 3d zone exhibited the peaks corresponding to Ce3+ species without the apparent presence of Ce4+ species, which was confirmed by the absence of the signal at 916.0 eV, characteristic of these species. The surface Al/Mg ratio (2.43) was slightly higher than the theoretical value in MgAl2O4 (Al/Mg= 2), which could infer Al migration from the FeCrAlloy to the surface. The results presented demonstrate that the metal species could be more easily reduced in the structure system compared to the powder systems, probably due to higher metal‒spinel interactions in the powder catalytic. It is probable that in the monolithic catalyst preparation procedure, the metal species present a weaker interaction with the spinel support. 3.5 Catalytic performance of structured catalysts Considering the performance of the powdered catalyst shown previously and looking to increase the conversion but always below the thermodynamic equilibrium, the structured system was initially evaluated using a W/F ratio of 1.9 mg mL-1 min, and a CH4:CO2 ratio of 1:1. As shown in Fig. 10 A, the CH4 and CO2 conversions were maintained at 23 % and 33 %, respectively, during the 48 h of the test, showing remarkable stability. In addition, the H2/CO ratio remained stable at approximately 0.8, further confirming the catalyst's performance under the conditions tested. After the stability test, the monolith was allowed to cool to room temperature under inert flow. The catalyst was then weighed and an accumulation of carbon deposits of 0.35 gC gcat -1 was observed. After analyzing the images taken with an optical lens, it was found that the formation of carbonaceous deposits occurred mainly at the outlet of the monolithic reactor (Fig. 10B). The decomposition of carbonaceous species deposited in the monolith was studied by TPO. The oxidation profile (not shown) showed an peak at 495 °C, which can be attributed to filamentous carbon, and a lower intensity peak at 650 °C, likely corresponding to carbonaceous species located farther from the catalyst particles. It is worth noting that this type of carbon could be present in the outer shell of the monolith, where no catalyst is deposited. To study the structured system under more severe conditions, the 13CoM‒2 structured catalyst was subjected to a continuous catalytic test under different reaction conditions (Fig. 11 ) to evaluate its activity and stability. The conditions were chosen based on the tests carried out with the powder catalysts. Initially, its performance was studied at W/F = 3.9 mg mL-1 min with a CH4:CO2= 1:1 ratio for two hours. The conversions for CH4 and CO2 were 29 % and 31 %, respectively, yielding a H2/CO ratio of 0.64. Subsequently, the W/F was reduced to 1.9 and then further to 0.9 mg mL-1 min. This reduction resulted in an increase in CO2 conversion and a decrease in methane conversion. A similar behavior was also observed in the powdered catalyst tested under different W/F values. After the catalytic tests, the monolith was subjected to a 15 h period at 550 °C in an argon atmosphere. After this hold time, the monolith was tested at W/F = 0.9 mg mL-1 min with a CH4:CO2 ratio of 1:1, demonstrating stability. Subsequently, the methane content in the feed was increased to 60 %, corresponding to a CH4:CO2 ratio of 2:1, which led to a decline in methane conversion and an increase in CO2 conversion. After the above tests were completed, the monolith was cooled in argon to room temperature, and its weight was recorded, revealing an accumulation of possible carbonaceous deposits of 0.3 gC gcat -1. Subsequently, the monolith was reloaded to be evaluated under the initial reaction conditions (W/F = 3.9 mg mL-1 min with a CH4:CO2= 1:1). Before evaluation, the monolith was subjected to a reduction treatment due to prior exposure to air. The results were quite promising since the monolith exhibited conversions very close to the initial values, indicating its stability throughout the diverse catalytic evaluations under inert atmosphere and elevated temperature. Moreover, the monolith demonstrated stability to on/off cycles, a behavior likely attributed to the high adherence of the catalytic coatings. These results have important implications, as they closely emulate the start‒up and shut‒down cycles of catalytic reactors employed in industrial applications. Metallic monoliths coated with Ni have exhibited remarkable durability in catalytic performance during the Steam Methane Reforming (SMR) reaction [43,44]. It is important to mention that subsequent to the experiments at 550 °C, the temperature was raised to 600 °C, and the performance of the monolith was tested with a CH4:CO2=1:1 ratio and W/F = 3.9 mg mL-1 min. The obtained conversions for methane (49 %) and CO2 (45 %) indicated the occurrence of methane decomposition reaction (results not included in Fig. 11). After 1 h of reaction, the system was cooled down, and its weight was determined, which was found to be similar to the weight obtained during the initial cooling cycle. As mentioned above, structured catalysts prepared on metallic monoliths exhibited several advantages compared to those based on cordierite monoliths. Despite this, few works have applied them to the dry reforming of methane (Table 4 ), using only Ni-based catalysts [19–21]. Furthermore, the reaction was evaluated at relatively high temperatures (≥700 °C) in all cases, been the stability test performed under thermodynamic equilibrium conditions in two of them. Besides, these works do not report a study of on-off cycles simulating a process stop nor an exhaustive study of the physicochemical properties after the evaluation. In this work the structured catalyst used in the reaction was subjected to a cutting and polishing procedure to be studied by SEM and determine the thickness of the catalytic layer and its composition. The SEM images of after a transverse cut are presented in Fig. 12 . Notably, the monolithic channels exhibited no discernible instances of plugging by carbonaceous deposits (Fig. 12A). Moreover, a thorough examination revealed that the catalytic coating remains adhered to the FeCrAlloy substrate, displaying an estimated thickness of approximately 1.6 µm. For illustrative purposes, an enlarged view of a monolithic wall region elucidates the metallic substrate, the catalytic coverage and the resin (Fig. 12B). The EDS analysis of the catalytic layer revealed its constituent elements (Co, Ce, Mg, Al, and O), as well as those from the substrate (Fe, Cr, and Al) (Fig. 12C). Remarkably, the Co/Ce ratio determined through EDS analysis (4.1) was close to the value derived from gravimetric measurements (3.5); the Al/Mg ratio showed a higher value than the nominal value, attributed to the depth of the analytical technique and to the aluminum from the substrate. Koo et al. achieved a thin coating (1.1 µm) for a monolithic catalyst coated with Ni nanolayers, which was prepared using a coating method based on the deposition‒precipitation technique developed by the "Korean Institute of Energy Research" (KIER). In comparison to the catalyst obtained through the conventional washcoating method (with a thickness of 21 µm), the catalyst produced using the KIER method exhibited enhanced Ni dispersion and increased availability of active sites [44]. 3.6 Comparison of structured and powder systems The performance of the structured catalyst was compared with the powder system varying the W/F and feed composition. These tests were carried out at 550 °C. At W/F = 3.9 mg mL-1 min with a CH4:CO2 ratio of 1:1. It was noted that the reactant conversions obtained with the monolith were higher than those achieved with the powder system (Fig. 13 A). This was more evident when the W/F was decreased (from 3.9 to 0.9) and the methane composition of the feed was increased from 32 to 60 % (Fig. 13B), the latter being very similar to the composition of a biogas. Under these conditions, the CH4 and CO2 conversions obtained with the powder were 5.9 and 17.7 %, while with the structured catalyst, conversions of 15.0 and 35.5 were achieved, respectively, and with a H2/CO ratio equal to 1. Based on the catalytic results, the monolithic system exhibited superior performance compared to the powder system, which can be attributed to notable enhancements in mass/heat transfer and a longer contact time of the reactants with the catalytic material. Our results are consistent with those reported by Sanjay et al. These authors carried out a comparison between a structured system and a powdered system, based on Rh‒Ni/MgAl2O4 catalytic material, in the SMR reaction, reporting a superior performance for the monolith and attributed the lower methane conversion in the powder system to the presence of mass and heat transfer limitations [45]. The obtained results highlight the potential of structured catalysts in enhancing catalytic efficiency and provide valuable insights for the design and optimization of catalytic systems in various industrial applications. 4 Conclusions Powder catalysts with varying cobalt content were developed using the wet impregnation method for evaluation in the DRM reaction. The catalytic results demonstrated that the system with higher Co content (13 wt%) exhibited superior performance in the reaction, potentially attributed to the increased availability of active sites (Co0) on the surface, as determined by XPS analysis. That catalyst displayed resistance to carbon deposition when operating at 550 °C and CH4:CO2 ratio of 1:1. Nevertheless, elevated reaction temperatures or increased methane composition in the feed led to the formation of carbonaceous species. The in-situ DRIFT analysis provided valuable insights into the DRM reaction mechanism, revealing the formation of carbonate and hydrogen carbonate species on the catalyst surface, which played a key role in the activation of CO2 and CH4. The data obtained from the powdered catalysts led us to select the optimal Co composition (∼13 wt%) to prepare a structured catalyst using FeCrAlloy monoliths. The thickness of the catalytic coating was 1.6 µm and exhibited high adhesion. The catalyst exhibited stability and selectivity towards H2 under different reaction conditions and on/off cycles. A comparison between the powder and structured systems revealed that metallic species were more readily reduced in the monolithic system, likely due to metal‒spinel interactions. Moreover, the monolithic reactor displayed enhanced catalytic performance, primarily attributed to improved heat transfer and extended contact time between reactants and the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: Cobalt-based powder catalysts with different Co loadings were synthesized via wet impregnation using MgAl2O4 spinel as support. The catalytic properties of the solids were evaluated in the dry-reforming methane at different reaction temperatures and two CH4:CO2 ratios. The catalyst with higher cobalt content (13 %) presented superior performance due to increased Co0 species availability, confirmed by XPS analysis. Besides, this catalyst displayed remarkable resistance to carbon deposition at 550 °C and CH4:CO2 1: 1 ratio. In-situ DRIFT measurements demonstrated the formation and transformation of carbonate and hydrogen carbonate species during the DRM reaction, highlighting efficient CO2 and CH4 activation on the catalyst surface. Based on this data, a structured catalyst was deposited on top of the FeCrAlloy monolith, which was active, stable, selective for H2, and resistant against on/off cycles. Compared with the powder catalyst, the structured system displayed higher catalytic activity, possibly due to higher reducibility of metal species and improved heat transfer provided by the FeCrAlloy substrate. The results highlight the potential of Co-based structured catalysts for H2 or synthesis gas production processes.
